conversation.content: So, um, you're really going to [joking] break into the observatory tonight with, like, just a paperclip and... what, exactly?

A paperclip, three magnets from my grandmother's fridge, and an expired campus ID from 2019. The security system hasn't been updated since the Cold War—I calculated a 97% success rate if we move during the guard's bathroom break.
You, uh, calculated his bathroom schedule? That's... well, that's actually kind of disturbing, you know?

Every Tuesday at 11:47 PM, like clockwork—poor guy has [warm] irritable bowel syndrome from the cafeteria chili. Look, I'm not proud of the surveillance, but astronomical discoveries wait for no one's digestive system.
What if, I mean, we get caught? My scholarship... honestly, my entire future depends on not, er, getting expelled.

Expelled? Please. We're not stealing anything—we're correcting a fundamental error in their asteroid trajectory calculations that could literally save humanity from extinction in 2087. If anything, they should give us honorary degrees.
You can't be serious about the asteroid thing.
Dead serious. Their margin of error is off by 0.0003%—sounds tiny, right? But compound that over sixty-three years and boom, we're talking Manhattan-sized space rock versus harmless fly-by.
Why not just... email them?
Tried that. Six times. They think I'm a crackpot undergraduate who watches too much sci-fi—which, fair, guilty as charged—but my math is solid.
Your "solid math" also said we could build a functioning rocket out of Diet Coke and Mentos.

That was different! The thrust-to-weight [laugh hard] ratio was theoretically sound until Karen from housing called the fire department. Besides, we got seventeen feet of vertical lift before structural failure—that's not nothing!
Okay so, um, hypothetically—and I'm [speeding up] not saying yes—but, like, how exactly would we, you know, even get past the main entrance?
Through the heating vents, obviously. I've been mapping the HVAC system for three months—Tuesday night they reduce airflow to save energy, making it perfectly safe for human traversal.
The vents? That's... actually, that's your plan? We're not, I mean, action heroes—well, you're barely five-foot-four!
Five-foot-three-and-three-quarters, thank you very much. And that's exactly why it'll work—I'm the perfect size for those ducts, plus I've been doing yoga specifically to prepare for this.
You've been doing yoga... to, er, prepare for breaking and entering? That's, honestly, the most you thing I've ever heard.

Look, it's basically just aggressive astronomy at this point. And, um, technically it's not breaking if nothing, you know, actually breaks—we're more like... temporarily borrowing their telescope to save Earth.
I can't believe I'm, well, even considering this. My mom would, like, literally kill me if she knew I was, uh, discussing felonies with the campus genius-slash-lunatic.

Genius-slash-lunatic? That's the nicest thing [flirtatious] anyone's called me all semester. Come on, when we save the world, your mom will forgive you—plus, I promise to name the asteroid after you when we're heroes.
